[[Centrism]]{{Cite journal |last=el-Karanshawi |first=Shaimaa |date=19 February 2011 |title=Egypt court approves moderate Islamic party |journal=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |accessdate=2011-02-20 |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/323634}} |national = |international = |affiliation1_title = |affiliation1 = |colors = Brown |blank1_title = |blank1 = |seats1_title = [[People's Assembly of Egypt |People's Assembly]] |seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|0|508|hex={{Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = |seats2 = |symbol = |flag = |website = http://www.alwasatparty.com/ |country = Egypt |footnotes = '''a'''{{note|Recognition}}: Legally recognized on 19 February 2011. }} '''''Hizb al-Wasat al-Jadid''''' ({{Lang-ar|Ø­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ³Ø· Ø§ÙØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯}}), translated in [[English language|English]] as the '''New Center Party''' but more commonly known as '''al-Wasat Party''', is a moderate [[Islam]]ist political party in [[Egypt]]. == Foundation == It was founded by {{link-interwiki|en=Abu al-Ila Madi|lang=ar|lang_title=Ø£Ø¨Ù Ø§ÙØ¹ÙØ§ ÙØ§Ø¶Ù}} in 1996 as a splinter group of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], whom Madi accused of having "narrow political horizons." The creation of al-Wasat was criticized by the Brotherhood, which said Madi was trying to split the movement.{{Cite news |title=New party shows deep political change in new Egypt |author=Mikhail, Sarah |author2=Perry, Tom |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110219 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-19}} It was also not well received by the Egyptian government, which brought its founders before a [[Military tribunal|military court]] on the charge of setting up a party as an Islamist front. Al-Wasat tried to gain an official license four times between 1996 and 2009, but its application was rejected each time by the political parties committee, which was chaired by a leading member of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]]. Political parties formed on the basis of religion have been banned by the [[Constitution of Egypt|Egyptian constitution]] since an amendment to Article 5 was [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2007|approved in 2007]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.cabinet.gov.eg/AboutEgypt/HTML/Constit_update2007_e.pdf |title=Constitutional Amendments of 2007 |publisher=[[Cabinet of Egypt]] |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |accessdate=2011-02-19}} === Recognition === Al-Wasat was granted official recognition on 19 February 2011 after a court in [[Cairo]] approved its establishment. The court's ruling was handed down in the wake of the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]], and made al-Wasat the first new party to gain official status after the [[Resignation of Hosni Mubarak|resignation]] of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]].{{Cite news |title=After 15-year wait, Egypt's Wasat Party approved |first=Tom |last=Perry |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/egypt-politics-party-idUSLDE71I06320110219 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-19}} Its newly acquired official status allows al-Wasat to compete in the [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|next parliamentary election]], and makes it the first legal party in Egypt with an Islamic background.{{Cite news |title=Egypt court approves country's first Islamic party |url=http://www.sify.com/news/egypt-court-approves-country-s-first-islamic-party-news-international-lctu4fiafed.html |format=Reprint |agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}{{Cite journal |date=19 February 2011 |title=Egypt licenses first moderate Islamic party |journal=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |accessdate=2011-02-20 |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=208916}} == Ideology == The party asserts that its aim is to promote a tolerant version of [[Islam]] with [[Liberal movements within Islam|liberal tendencies]]. Its founder Madi highlights as proof of this openness the fact that two [[Copts]] and three women are among the party's 24 top members.{{Cite news |title=After years of trying, moderate Islamic party gets official recognition in post-Mubarak Egypt |first=Maamoun |last=Youssef |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5jqgqVZUjLjXbA31l70QPM4H-X8GQ?docId=6004567 |agency=[[Canadian Press Enterprises Inc.|CP]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-20}} According to the [[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]], al-Wasat "seeks to interpret Islamic [[sharia]] principles in a manner consistent with the values of a liberal democratic system. Although al-Wasat advocates a political system that is firmly anchored in Islamic law, it also views sharia principles as flexible and wholly compatible with the principles of pluralism and equal citizenship rights." The party's manifesto accepts the right of a Christian to become head of state in a Muslim-majority country.
